subject: Re: [junit] Re: Help with Junitreport
msgSnippet: Hi Shan, Presuming that there are TEST-*.xml results in ${testreports.dir}, your  task looks fine (although I d probably want to make the todir
messageBody:
Hi Shan,

Presuming that there are TEST-*.xml results in ${testreports.dir}, your
<junitreport> task looks fine (although I'd probably want to make the
"todir" different to the home of the XML reports).

You can check the operation of Ant when <junitreport> is being executed
by specifying -debug on the Ant command line. The name of each xml test
result file will then be printed to the console as it is processed.

Cheers,
-Brendan
http://www.thecortex.net

shankris72 wrote:

> The TEST-*.xml does get generated and unfortunately I don't have
> access to it till monday when I will be at work. Will probably post it
> then.
> Anyway, thanks
> Shan
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
> > shankris72 wrote:
> >
> > <junitreport todir="${testreports.dir}">
> > <fileset dir="${testreports.dir}"
> > includes="TEST-*.xml"/>
> > <report todir="${testreports.dir}"
> > format="frames"/>
> > </junitreport>
> >
> > Look in the directory ${testreports.dir}. Are there really TEST-*.xml
> > files in there?
> > --
> > J. B. Rainsberger,
> > Diaspar Software Services
> > http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
> > Let's write software that people understand
